commander.name: Unknown
commander.previous_service: Commander identity not preserved in US G2 July 1943 intelligence document

supply_logistics.supply_status: Critical - Tunisia bridgehead under siege, April-May 13 1943. Division destroyed at Axis surrender. Supply lines from Sicily completely interdicted by Allied air and naval forces. Fuel, ammunition, and food critically short.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal hills and valleys of northern Tunisia

subordinate_units.note: Young Fascists militia unit converted to infantry regiment

subordinate_units.equipment: 75/27 and 100/17 guns, 47/32 AT guns, 20mm AA guns

subordinate_units.note: CCRR = Corpo dei Carabinieri Reali (Royal Military Police)

tactical_doctrine.role: Defensive infantry division in Tunisia bridgehead final phase
special_capabilities: Young Fascists militia background - political reliability emphasis
known_issues: Limited combat experience compared to veteran North Africa divisions
Depleted strength due to supply shortages
Militia origin - less professional training than regular army divisions
Critically short of ammunition and fuel by April 1943
Surrounded in Tunisia bridgehead with no escape route
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Limited - division formed from Young Fascists militia, deployed to Tunisia late in campaign without extensive desert experience

special_rules: Young Fascists political background - high political indoctrination
Limited combat experience in North Africa theater
Destroyed at Axis surrender May 13, 1943 - all personnel POW
historical_engagements: Formed from Young Fascists (Giovani Fascisti) militia organization 1940-1941
Deployed to Tunisia theater late 1942 or early 1943
Final defensive operations Tunisia bridgehead April-May 1943
Renamed 'Cacciatori d'Africa' shortly before final surrender

source: Order of Battle of the Italian Army - USA HQ G2 July 1943 (PRIMARY SOURCE - lines 4578-4589)

Young Fascists (Giovani Fascisti) militia organization documentation

command.commander.name.reason: Commander name not preserved in US G2 July 1943 intelligence document. Division destroyed May 1943, commander likely captured or killed.
sources_checked: Order of Battle of the Italian Army - USA HQ G2 July 1943
command.commander.name.mitigation: Additional Italian military archives research required. Postwar POW records may contain commander identity.

exact_battalion_organization.reason: US G2 document lists regiment/battalion names but not detailed internal organization. Standard Italian infantry division structure used for estimates.
sources_checked: Order of Battle of the Italian Army - USA HQ G2 July 1943
TM E 30-420 Italian Military Forces 1943 (organizational templates)
Comparative data from other Italian infantry divisions 1943
exact_battalion_organization.estimate_method: Applied standard Italian infantry division 1943 structure (binary division type) with adjustments for autotrasportabile (truck-mobile) configuration and Tunisia campaign depletion.

precise_personnel_counts.reason: No strength returns available for this division. Estimated based on standard Italian infantry division establishment reduced 30-40% for Tunisia campaign depletion.
sources_checked: Order of Battle of the Italian Army - USA HQ G2 July 1943
Tunisia campaign strength data for other Italian divisions
precise_personnel_counts.estimate_method: Standard Italian infantry division: 10,000 personnel at full strength. Reduced to ~7,200 for Tunisia Q2 1943 conditions (30% depletion from combat losses, disease, supply shortages).

detailed_equipment_variants.reason: Specific equipment allocations not documented. Used standard Italian infantry division equipment scaled for reduced personnel strength.
sources_checked: Order of Battle of the Italian Army - USA HQ G2 July 1943
Jane's WW2 Tanks and Fighting Vehicles for Italian AFV data
detailed_equipment_variants.estimate_method: Applied standard Italian infantry division equipment ratios adjusted for autotrasportabile type (more trucks, fewer heavy weapons) and Tunisia depletion (20-30% equipment losses).

deployment_history_details.reason: Formation date and pre-Tunisia service not fully documented. Known: formed from Young Fascists militia, deployed Tunisia late 1942/early 1943, destroyed May 13 1943.
sources_checked: Order of Battle of the Italian Army - USA HQ G2 July 1943
Young Fascists (Giovani Fascisti) militia organization records
Tunisia Campaign order of battle documents
deployment_history_details.mitigation: Italian militia conversion records and Tunisia deployment manifests would clarify exact formation and deployment dates.

data_quality_notes: TIER 3 EXTRACTION - Limited source data available
US G2 July 1943 document provides only basic organizational structure (regiments/battalions)
Division destroyed at Tunisia surrender May 13, 1943 - only 43 days of Q2 1943
Personnel and equipment estimates based on standard Italian infantry division structure reduced for Tunisia campaign conditions
Young Fascists militia origin: division formed from Giovani Fascisti (16-18 year old Fascist youth organization)
Renamed 'Cacciatori d'Africa' (African Hunters) before final surrender - political renaming
No tanks - infantry division, not armored (despite militia background)
Confidence 52% due to missing commander, limited operational details, and estimated strengths

historical_notes.formation_history: Formed from Young Fascists (Giovani Fascisti) militia organization. The Giovani Fascisti was the 16-18 year old cohort of Italy's fascist youth movement (Gioventù Italiana del Littorio - GIL). In 1940, volunteer battalions of Young Fascists were enlisted into 24 special battalions for military service. The 136th Division was formed from these militia units and designated an infantry division (autotrasportabile - truck-mobile type).
historical_notes.tunisia_deployment: Deployed to Tunisia theater late 1942 or early 1943 as Axis forces retreated from Libya into Tunisia bridgehead. Division participated in final defensive operations April-May 1943 as Allied forces compressed the Axis perimeter. Renamed 'Cacciatori d'Africa' (African Hunters) shortly before final surrender - a political/propaganda renaming to remove the 'Young Fascists' militia association.
historical_notes.final_destruction: Division destroyed at Axis surrender in Tunisia on May 13, 1943. All personnel became prisoners of war. Tunisia capitulation marked the end of Axis resistance in North Africa, with 275,000 German and Italian troops surrendering. The 136th was among the Italian divisions that ceased to exist as combat formations at this surrender.
historical_notes.equipment_status_q2_1943: By Q2 1943, division critically short of fuel, ammunition, and supplies due to Allied interdiction of supply lines from Sicily. Tunisia bridgehead completely isolated with no resupply possible. Equipment depleted through combat losses and lack of replacements. Division likely at 60-70% of authorized equipment strength by April 1943.
historical_notes.young_fascists_background: The Young Fascists militia was a paramilitary youth organization emphasizing political indoctrination and pre-military training. Units formed from this organization had high political reliability but less professional military training compared to regular Italian Army divisions. The militia background meant emphasis on political ideology over tactical proficiency.
historical_notes.quarter_coverage: Quarter 1943-Q2 covers April-June 1943. Division was operational only April 1 - May 13 (43 days). Division destroyed at Tunisia surrender May 13, 1943. Remainder of quarter (May 14 - June 30) division did not exist as fighting formation - all personnel POW.
historical_notes.cacciatori_d_africa_rename: US G2 document notes division renamed 'CACCIATORI D'AFRICA' (African Hunters) before destruction. This was likely a propaganda/morale measure to remove the militia 'Young Fascists' designation and give the unit a more martial identity during the Tunisia final phase. The rename did not affect the division's tactical organization or combat effectiveness.
